title: A train traveling at a uniform speed clear a platform 200 m long in 10 seconds and passes a telephone post in 5 seconds. What is the speed of the train? - Quora

response.answer_text: Let length of the train be (x) m When the train passes the platform Distance covered would be length of the platform + length of the train. D = 200 + x T = 10 se. S = d/t =200 + x / 10 Hence the first eq. Is formed. Similarly, when the train passes the telephone post. The total distance covered would be equal to the length of the train. Here we neglect the width of the post because it is too small and has a neglegible effect on the value. D = x T = 5 sec S= x/5 ….. eq. 2 Equating eq. 1 and 2 we get, 200 + x = 2x X = 200m Putting the value of x in eq. 2 will give us the speed of the train. Therefore, Speed of the train = 40 m/s Hope found me helpful.

In the first case (pole) :- Let the length of train be x.  We observe that as it passes the pole the distance covered = the length of train i.e. x Therefore - Distance(s) = [math]x m[/math] Time(t) = [math]5 s[/math] Speed(v) = [math]\dfrac{s}{t} = \dfrac{x}{5}[/math] In the second case (platform) :-  We observe that as it passes the platform the distance covered = length of train +length of platform i.e. 200 + x Therefore - Distance(s)= [math]200+x m[/math] Time (t) = [math]10 s[/math] Speed(v) = [math]\dfrac{s}{t} = \dfrac {200+x}{10}[/math] As speed is constant - Speed in first case = Speed in second case [math]\implies \dfrac{x}{5}= \dfrac{200+x}{10}[/math] [math]\implies x = 200[/math] Calculating the speed - In first case [math]v= \dfrac{x}{5}[/math] [math]=\dfrac {200}{5}[/math] [math]= 40 m/s [/math] Ans.
